item.title: 2K Shutting Down Servers For These Two Games Soon
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's the end of the road for two 2K Sports titles, at least for their online services. The publisher has announced that the servers for two aging golf games--The Golf Club 2019 featuring PGA Tour and PGA Tour 2K21--will go offline on October 30, 2025.

As of August 30, however, 2K Sports removed the ability to purchase any virtual currency for either game. Beyond that, however, the publisher said players "won't see any effect."

On October 30, 2K will close the servers for both titles, meaning each game's store, along with all online game modes and functionality--including progression rewards--will no longer be available.

2K Sports informed players of these changes in an email.

The publisher did not provide a reason for why the servers are going offline, but it's not uncommon for online servers for older games to close down over time. The games feature official PGA Tour licensed content, so expiring contracts could be a factor as well.

Released in 2018, The Golf Club 2019 featuring PGA Tour was the first game in the series to feature the PGA Tour branding. There was no entry in the series in 2019, but the franchise came back in 2020 as PGA Tour 2K21. PGA Tour 2K23 was released in 2022, followed by PGA Tour 2K25 in 2025.

PGA Tour 2K25 is the No. 16 best-selling game for 2025 so far. The series is developed by HB Studios, which Take-Two acquired in 2021.

item.title: Final Fantasy Tactics Remake Could Lead To New Content Or A Sequel
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There could be new content added to the Final Fantasy Tactics remake--and even a full-fledged sequel somewhere down the line--but that will require fans putting money where their mouths are with Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles. However, that's not a guarantee.

Speaking with Wired, game director Kazutoyo Maehiro discussed possibly adding features from 2007's Final Fantasy Chronicles: War of the Lions release on PlayStation Portable to the remake. “Our first and foremost goal here really was to recreate the original game,” said Maehiro. He acknowledged fan feedback for that content, such as the Onion Knight and Black Knight classes, but "cannot make any promises" about them coming eventually to The Ivalice Chronicles.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Final Fantasy Tactics - The Ivalice Chronicles Hands on Impressions

The remake will introduce a new difficulty option called Squire, which is aimed at helping newcomers to the spinoff series and genre. In addition, The Ivalice Chronicles does utilize the script from War of the Lions for the classic version included with the remake. As for a proper sequel to Final Fantasy Tactics, that will depend on the game's reception and sales.

"If [The Ivalice Chronicles] were to become a success, I do feel that that would then lead to discussions around potentially bringing out sequels, for example, or newer tactical RPGs," said Maehiro, who served as events planner for the original Final Fantasy Tactics in 1997. Earlier this year, the original's art director talked about becoming obsessed with Final Fantasy Tactics running at 60fps on PlayStation.

The Final Fantasy Tactics remake was announced at the PlayStation State of Play event in June. The RPG is set to launch September 30 on PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox Series X|S, Switch, and Switch 2. In fact, there will be a free Switch 2 upgrade for The Ivalice Chronicles, though no physical edition for the new hybrid console.

item.title: Get Free Call Of Duty Double XP And Battle Pass Tier Skips Just For Logging In Soon
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Activision has announced some nice new perks for the upcoming launch of Black Ops 6 Season 5 Reloaded, including battle pass tier skips and double XP.

To celebrate the Black Ops 7 announcement, Activision is offering up 20 free battle pass tier skips for anyone who simply logs in to Black Ops 6 or Warzone now through September 16.

Additionally, Activision is giving everyone who downloads the upcoming Season 5 Reloaded update a pack of double XP tokens for player XP, weapon XP, and battle pass XP. Everyone who downloads the Season 5 Reloaded update and logs in to the Call of Duty HQ app through October 1 will get:

  • Five 1-Hour Double Player XP Tokens (5 hours total)
  • Five 1-Hour Double Weapon XP Tokens (5 hours total)
  • Five 1-Hour Double Battle Pass XP Tokens (5 hours total)

Activision also clarified today that the Season 5 Reloaded downloaded will be "larger on some platforms" due to how the company is "reorganizing" certain Call of Duty content to prepare for the Black Ops 7 multiplayer beta in October. Activision did not reveal the exact file size, however.

Black Ops 6 and Warzone Season 5 Reloaded launches on September 4, featuring new maps, modes, weapons, and more. Head to Activision's blog to see a complete rundown of what to expect.

In other Call of Duty news, Paramount has announced a deal with Activision to make a Call of Duty movie and potentially a TV series. Paramount boss David Ellison said he is a "lifelong fan" of Call of Duty who has spent "countless hours" playing Call of Duty games over the years. Paramount and Activision said they are working together to honor the franchise's "rich narrative and distinctive style" with the movie.

item.title: Get WWE 2K25 And Seven More Games For Just $15 At Humble This Month
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The September 2025 lineup of PC games for Humble Choice subscribers has been revealed, and this month, you can headline Wrestlemania, become a legend amongst Guardians, and return to Monkey Island.

If you haven't heard of it yet, Humble Choice is a $15 monthly subscription service that offers a monthly batch of PC games that are yours to keep forever, even if you decide to cancel your membership. There are other perks to this membership as well, including exclusive discounts at the Humble Store and access to the Humble Vault--an additional rotating library of games that's only available to members.

Humble Choice September 2025 Games

  • WWE 2K25
  • Destiny 2: Legacy Collection
  • The Plucky Squire
  • Spellforce: Conquest of Eo
  • Return to Monkey Island
  • Eastern Exorcist
  • Warhammer 40,000: Speed Freeks
  • Grapple Dog

WWE 2K25 is the main event this month, as the new entry annual sports entertainment series was released not too long ago. Outside of the microtransaction-riddled social space known as The Island, this year's game is everything you'd expect from the franchise: polished, wild, and full of modes that'll allow you to go from NXT hopeful to a superstar that the crowd must acknowledge.

If you've been itching to try out Destiny 2, the Legacy Collection will help you get started once you've downloaded the free-to-play base edition of the game. It includes the expansions The Witch Queen, Lightfall, and The Final Shape, as well as several pieces of DLC that'll arm your Guardian for the tough fights that lie ahead of them in this exciting sci-fi FPS game. One thing to note here is that the codes for this content won't be valid for long, as you'll only have until October 7 to redeem them.

Another great game here is Return to Monkey Island, the 2022 follow-up to Monkey Island 2. Featuring the classic point-and-click puzzle-solving gameplay of the original games--alongside some welcome quality-of-life changes--Return to Monkey Island is an old-school adventure with a striking sense of style.

As a reminder, all these games are available at no additional cost to Humble Choice members as part of their $15/month subscription. You can sign up now and gain immediate access to them all, and they're yours to download and keep forever.

You'll also get all the other membership perks, including the Humble Vault--which is a rotating library of even more games exclusive to members--and special Humble Store discounts. Additionally, 5% of every Humble Choice membership is donated to charity, and proceeds this month will go to Team Rubicon.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Perfect Dark Reboot Almost Got A Second Chance At Take-Two--Report
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Perfect Dark, canceled in July amidst a wave of layoffs at Microsoft, almost got a second chance at life thanks to Take-Two, according to a new report. However, talks to see the game be revived have apparently fallen through.

According to Bloomberg (and corroborated by VGC), Tomb Raider developer Crystal Dynamics, which was working with the now shuttered Xbox studio The Initiative to develop the Perfect Dark reboot, could have continued working on the game. Crystal Dynamics' parent company, the Embracer Group, had spent the last two months since its cancellation looking for a publisher, and most recently had looked to strike a deal with publisher Take-Two to purchase the game from Microsoft.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Perfect Dark Gameplay Reveal Trailer | Xbox Games Showcase 2024

The report states that the deal for Take-Two to take over the funding and publishing of Perfect Dark fell apart at least partially because all the parties involved were not able to come to terms over who would have long-term ownership of the Perfect Dark franchise, which currently still resides with Microsoft. Crystal Dynamics laid off an unspecified number of staff last week as a result of the deal with Take-Two collapsing, according to Bloomberg.

Perfect Dark was announced in 2020 as a reboot of the dormant sci-fi shooter franchise to be in development at Microsoft's first "AAAA" studio The Initiative. In 2021, it was announced Crystal Dynamics would step in to help as the game's co-developer. After years of radio silence, a gameplay trailer for Perfect Dark, revealing it to be a first-person shooter with what looked to be immersive-sim elements, was revealed in 2024 as part of an Xbox showcase.

A report from shortly before Perfect Dark's gameplay-trailer debut stated the reboot was in rough shape and hadn't come together, despite assistance from Crystal Dynamics.

Microsoft's July layoffs saw the tech giant reduce its headcount by an estimated 4%, resulting in around 9,000 people losing their jobs. Among them were those who worked at The Initiative, which was shuttered as a result of the layoffs. Other games canceled alongside Perfect Dark included a new MMORPG from The Elder Scrolls Online developer ZeniMax Online and Rare's long-in-development Everwild.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Won't Have Ray Tracing In Order To "Focus On Performance"
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Battlefield 6 won't have ray tracing, as the team instead is focusing on performance and optimization, according to the game's technical director.

In an interview with ComicBook, Ripple Effect (one of the studios that comprises Battlefield Studios) technical director Christian Buhl said it doesn't have plans for ray tracing at launch or in the near future.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Battlefield 6 - Official PC Features Overview Trailer

"That was because we wanted to focus on performance," Buhl said. "We wanted to make sure that all of our effort was focused on making the game as [optimized] as possible for the default settings and default users."

The decision to not include ray tracing was made "early on" Buhl said. In a separate interview, Buhl may have revealed why ray tracing wasn't a priority for the team, stating that a "meaningful percentage" of players during the Battlefield 6 beta were using minimum recommended specs or below.

"Min spec is certainly one of our most important specs," Bruhl said. "It's super important from both a commercial and business perspective--we want as many people as possible playing the game."

An emphasis on ray-tracing would definitely go against that philosophy of looking to ensure the game plays well on as wide a range of PCs as possible. In yet another interview, Bruhl lamented the need for Battlefield 6's Secure Boot requirement on PC, something that caused headaches for some players and left them unable to participate in the beta. He stated he wished "everyone could play" but that Secure Boot is needed to prevent cheaters and make it easier for EA to detect them.

EA recently revealed Battlefield 6's PC specs for launch, even as recent leaks from its Battlefield Labs playtests have revealed more about Battlefield 6's larger maps and its battle royale mode.

Those excited for Battlefield 6 won't have to wait long, as the game launches on PC, Xbox Series X|S, and PlayStation 5 on October 10. In the meantime, players can play Battlefield 2042 to unlock free Battlefield 6 cosmetics as part of the game's "Road To Battlefield 6" event.

Click here to add GameSpot as a preferred source on Google.
